introduction.p: Believe it or not, you are already familiar with electric potential. In everyday language we call it voltage. When you have a 1.5\text{-volt} battery, it provides 1.5\text{ volts} of electric potential difference between + and -. So, what is electric potential?

To get a feel for the concept, consider moving a charge +Q near another charge +q as shown in . Suppose you move so that your force is only an infinitesimal greater than needed to balance the electric force so that the speed of Q does not change. Then, by conservation of energy, work done by you will go towards changing the potential energy of Q. Since, we worked against electric force only, this potential energy is called electric potential energy (EPE).
\text{Change in EPE} = \text{Work done against electric force}.

figure.caption: Moving a test charge Q near another charge q. Suppose, while moving, you balance the electric force F_e by q by your force, F_\text{you}. The work by F_\text{you} will go towards changing electrical potential energy (EPE) of Q.

introduction.p: The reason we insist that charge does not acccelerate as we move it from one point to another is that we want work against only the electric force, and by balancing the electric force by an applied force, we can find the corresponding work by the applied force. If applied force is not balancing the electric force, charge would accelerate and energy conservation will require accounting for kinetic energy change as well.
Denoting work by you by W_{1\rightarrow 2}^{\text{by you}} and potential energy of Q by letter U, we can write Eq. in symbols as follows.

Its important to note that work is equal to change in potential energy, not potential energy itself. For potential energy of Q at a point, say P_2, we select a reference point at which we choose a reference value. So, if we choose P_1 to reference point and choose potential energy to be zero there, Eq. can be used to assign potential energy at P_2.
Note further that work by you can be positive or negative. If you do a positive work, then you will be putting more energy into Q and if you do negative work, you will be extracting energy from Q.

sidebyside.p: For instance, if you move a positive Q towards a positive q, then, you will need to put energy into Q; that is, you will have to do a positive work. However, if you were to move positive Q towards a negative q, you will have to do negative work on Q, thereby removing energy from Q.

introduction.p: In Eq. , work will depend on charge Q - higher the charge higher the work; hence, potential energy will depend on charge Q as well. If we divide this work by Q, we will obtain a quantity that is indepdent of the test charge Q and reflects influence of electric field between P_1 and P_2. This is similar to how we obtained electric field from electric force.

The quantity obtained by dividing change in EPE by test charge Q is called change in electric potential. We will choose to denote it by \phi although you will see it denoted by letter V as well. Thus,
\phi_2-\phi_1 = \dfrac{U_2-U_1}{Q}.

To define electric potential at a point, and not the potential difference between two points, we select a point in space as a reference point and assign a referene value, which is usually zero, to the potential there.
\phi_P = \dfrac{ W_{\text{ref}\rightarrow P}^{\text{by you}} }{Q} = \dfrac{ U_P - U_\text{ref} }{Q}.
The reference point must be chosen carefully to be a point where electric potential is well-defined. For instance, it is custmary to choose point at \infty when we are dealing with electric potential fo charges that are distributed in a finite space, and at a finite place when charges may extend to infinity.
The fundamental formula of electric potential is that from a charge q.

sidebyside.p:
We will derive the following formula in a later section for electric potential at a distance r from this charge, regardless of the direction from the charge, to be
\phi = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{q}{r},\ \ \text{reference zero at }r=\infty.

introduction.p: A positive charge, q\gt 0 will produce a positive potential and a negative charge q\lt 0 a negative potential.

sidebyside.p:
We will use this formula for potential from a point charge to deduce electric potential of line of charges with charge denssity \lambda at a distance s from the line to be
\phi = -\frac{1}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\ln \frac{s}{s_\text{ref}},\ \ \text{reference zero at }s_\text{ref}.

We will also find that electric potential between two oppositely charged plates of charge densities \pm\sigma increases from reference zero at negative plate towards positive plate linearly with distance. Therefore, at a distance z from the negative plate
\phi = \frac{\sigma}{\epsilon_0}\; z,\ \ \text{reference zero at negative plate at }z=0.

introduction.p: These formulas are given here to illustrate that you need to be aware that, in addition to the fundamental formula, Eq. , you have many other formulas in other charge distributions. However, the most fundamental is the definition of electric potential in terms of work done per unit charge, given in Eq. . We will use this defining equation to deduce all these other formulas in later sections.

p.alert: Advantage of Electric Potential over Electric Field

introduction.p: Both electric potential and electric field tell us about electrical influences of charges in a region of space. But since electric potential is related to how energy of a test particle changes, it is just a scalar real number and not a vector. That is why, it is much easier to work with electric potential than electric field. In the next section we will see electric potential maps just as we studied electric field maps in earlier chapters.

Electric potential in a region tells us how electric potential energy of a test particle will change in that region. From Eq. we can see that potential energy of a test charge Q at a point where potential is \phi is simply
U = Q\, \phi.

Since SI unit of energy is Joule, \text{J}, the SI unit of electric potential will be
\text{ J/C },
which is also called \text{volt}, denoted by \text{V}.

Electric potential energy of elementary particles are often too small when expressed in Joule. In these applications, it is often preferable to use the potential energy of an electron with charge in units of e in a place where potential is -1\text {V}. This energy is called an electron volt, \text{eV} .
1.0 \text{ eV} = 1.60 \times 10^{-19}\text{ J}.

subsection.title: Electric Potential in a Constant Electric Field Region

sidebyside.p: Suppose we have a region of constant electric field, for instance, between two parallel oppositely charged plates as shown in . Let us denote the electric field by \vec E. Then, if we move a test charge Q in this field from P_1 to P_2 with zero acceleration, the balancing applied force, -Q\vec E, would do the following work

subsection.p:
W \amp = -Q \vec E\cdot \vec r = QE r\cos(\pi-\theta) \amp = QE r\cos\,\theta = QE(x_2-x_1).
This work will equal the potential energy difference for the test charge between two points is
U_2 - U_1 = QE(x_2-x_1).
Dividing this by the test charge will give the potential difference
\phi_2 - \phi_1 = E(x_2-x_1).
If we take reference zero potential at x_1=0, i.e., P_1 at the negative plate with \phi_1=0, then, electric potential at an arbitrary point between the plates with x coordinate x will have electric potential \phi given by
\phi = E\;x.
That is, potential increases linearly with distance from negative plate towards positive plate. By setting x=d, we note that the positive plate has potential Ed with respect to the negative plate, which is at reference zero.

exercise.title: Electric Potential Difference from Change in Potential Energy

statement.p: You move a + 2\ \mu\text{C} charge Q from some point P_1 to another point P_2 such that the charge does not accelerate at any point in its path. If the energy Q increased by 5.0\ \mu\text{J}. What is the electric potential difference \phi_2 - \phi_1?

solution.p:
We use the definition of electric potential difference.
\phi_2-\phi_1 \amp = \dfrac{U_2-U_1}{Q}, \amp = \dfrac{5.0\ \mu\text{J}}{2\ \mu\text{C}} = 2.5\text{ J/C} = 2.5\text{ V}.

exercise.title: Electric Potential Difference from Changes in Potential and Kinetic Energy

statement.p: You move a + 2\ \mu\text{C} charge Q from some point P_1 to another point P_2 but applied force does not fully balance the electric force. There are no other forces when the particle is moving. As a result, we find that in addition to 5.0\ \mu\text{N.m} of work by the external force, the charge has increased kinetic energy of 7.0\ \mu\text{J}. What is the electric potential difference \phi_2 - \phi_1?

hint.p: Think what would have happened had there been no acceleration.

solution.p:
The definition of electric potential energy requires balancing all of electric force. Had we applied a balancing force, we would have to do additional negative work to absorb the part of the eletric force that was not balanced. Therefore,
U_2-U_1 = W_\text{by F} - \Delta \text{KE} = 5.0 -7.0 = -2.0\ \mu\text{J}.
We then use the definition of electric potential difference.
\phi_2-\phi_1 \amp = \dfrac{U_2-U_1}{Q}, \amp = \dfrac{-2.0\ \mu\text{J}}{2\ \mu\text{C}} = -1.0\text{ J/C} = -1.0\text{ V}.

exercise.title: Electric Potential Energy from Electric Potential Difference

statement.p: The positive terminal of a battery is at a potential of 1.5\text{ V} with zero potential reference at the negative terminal.
(a) What is the electric potential energy of a 2.0\ \mu\text{C} charge when it is placed at (i) the positive terminal, (ii) at the negative terminal?
(b) What is the electric potential energy of a -2.0\ \mu\text{C} charge when it is placed at (i) the positive terminal, (ii) at the negative terminal?
(c) How much work must you do in moving a 5.0\ \mu\text{C} from the positive terminal to the negative terminal without any acceleration?
(d) How much work must you do in moving a -5.0\ \mu\text{C} from the positive terminal to the negative terminal without any acceleration?

hint.p: (a) and (b) use definition, (c) and (d) use energy conservation to argue about how much work you need to provide.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
By using relation between electric potential at a point and electric potential energy of a charge placed at that point, we can get
\amp \text{(i)}\ \ U_{+} = Q\phi_{+} = 2.0\ \mu\text{C} \times 1.5\text{ V} = 3.0\ \mu\text{J}, \amp \text{(ii)}\ \ U_{-} = Q\phi_{-} = 0.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
By using relation between electric potential at a point and electric potential energy of a charge placed at that point, we can get
\amp \text{(i)}\ \ U_{+} = Q\phi_{+} = - 2.0\ \mu\text{C} \times 1.5\text{ V} = -3.0\ \mu\text{J}, \amp \text{(ii)}\ \ U_{-} = Q\phi_{-} = 0.

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
Work done must provide the change in energy.
W \amp = U_{-} - U_{+}, \amp = 0 - 5\times 1.5 = -7.5\ \mu\text{J}.

solution.title: (d)
solution.p:
Work done must provide the change in energy.
W \amp = U_{-} - U_{+}, \amp = 0 - (-5)\times 1.5 = +7.5\ \mu\text{J}.

exercise.title: Practice with Joule and Electron Volt Conversions

statement.p: A proton moves from a spot with potential equal to 200 V to another place where potential is 500 V. What is the change in potential energy in eV and in Joules?

solution.p:
Using e for charge on a proton, we get the following for the change in the potential energy of the proton.
\Delta U \amp = Q\Delta \phi \amp = e \times (500 - 200)\text{ V} = 300\text{ eV}.
We can express this in Joules by using the numerical value of the electronic charge e in \text{C} since \text{J}=\text{C.V}.
300\text{ eV} = 300\times 1.60\times 10^{-19} = 4.80\times 10^{-17}\text{ J}.

exercise.title: Speed of a Charge Released in the Neighborhood of a Fixed Charge

statement.p: Consider a charge Q_1 (+5\ \mu\text{C}) fixed at some point. Another charge Q_2 (\text{charge } +3\ \text{nC},\ \text{mass } 6\ \mu\text{g}) moves in the neighboring space.
(a) Evaluate potential energy of Q_2 when it is 4\text{ cm} from Q_1.
(b) If Q_2 is released at rest at a point 4\text{ cm} from Q_1, what will be its speed when it is 8\text{ cm} from Q_1. (Note: Q_1 is held fixed in its place.)

hint.p: (a) Use definition, (b) use conservation of energy.

solution.title: (a)
(b)
solution.p:
(b) The conservation of energy of the particle Q_2, namely,
\left[K + U \right]_i = \left[K + U \right]_f,
gives
0 + 3.4\times 10^{-3} = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 6\times 10^{-9} v^2 + 1.7\times 10^{-3},
which we can solve for the speed v,
v = \sqrt{3.4\times 10^{-3} / 6\times 10^{-9} } = 750\:\text{m/s}.

exercise.title: Electric Potential Difference in the Region of Constant Electric Field

statement.p: In a region of space, electric field is uniform, meaning same magnitude and same direction. For instance, in the space between two oppositely charges plates. Find the electric potential differences (a) \phi_B - \phi_A (b) \phi_D - \phi_C, and (c) \phi_H - \phi_G.

solution.p:
In the case constant electric field regions, the potential difference is easy to calculate from the displacement vector and the electric field.
\Delta \phi = -E\, d\, \cos\, \theta.
(a) Since \theta = 90^\circ, \cos\,\theta = 0, giving
\Delta\phi = 0.

(b) We will simply have \Delta \phi = -E\, d\, \cos\, \theta . Since CD direction makes less than 90^\circ with the direction of electric field, this will be negative. Another way to check the sign is to look at which side is closer to the positive charges - that side will be at a higher potential.

(c) Since \theta = 0^\circ, \cos\,\theta = 1. This gives \Delta \phi = -Ed. This is negative since H is down in the direction of electric field from G. Another way to check the sign is to look at which side is closer to the positive charges - that side will be at a higher potential.
